[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: Isobel - Isobel Thorm?
Narrator: *Her breath catches; you notice a barely-perceptible shudder run through her body.*
Isobel: An unfortunate coincidence. I hope never to meet the wicked man who haemorrhaged shadows over this peaceful village. I've heard you might be the person to stop him.
Isobel: A True Soul with a soul. Imagine.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I'm glad you've remembered who needs whose help here.
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I am already protected. My Lady shields me from the curse.
Isobel: For now, perhaps. But Shar can be fickle, and her love can prove fleeting. Do not turn your back on an advantage you may need... even a Sel√ªnite one.
Isobel: If nothing else, it can aid any companions who travel with you - somehow I doubt Shar's largesse was extended to them.
Player: It was nothing. Put it out of your mind.
Narrator: *But was it truly nothing? The pain gripped you tight, robbing you of all composure for a moment...*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: It won't be enough to protect you against areas of utter darkness, though - where the curse is strongest. This lantern should, though.
Player: Wait - Marcus is a True Soul, you know. And not the good kind, like me.

Astarion: I can't believe you let me do that. Killing all those people.
Astarion: A pleasant surprise.
Player: I wanted what was best for you.
Astarion: You sweet, sweet thing. I want what's best for you too, of course.
Astarion: And one wicked turn deserves another.
Astarion: So, tell me what you desire. What can I do for my dearest pet?
Player: I am not your pet.
Astarion: Oh don't be such a humourless little wretch - it's nothing but a joke.
Player: Then stop joking around and let's sleep together.
Astarion: You've earned it.
Astarion: But don't you want more - don't you want eternity? One more bite is all it would take?
Astarion: But if you want the gift of eternity, I can certainly offer you that. One little bite is all it would take.
Astarion: It would mean your salvation. Your eternity, despite that thing inside you.
Astarion: That's what you want, isn't it? To be mine? Forever?
Player: So what would I be? A vampire? Or your spawn?
Astarion: You wouldn't just be some spawn - you're far more than that to me.
Astarion: My dark consort. My right hand. My most beloved spawn.
Player: A beloved slave is still a slave.
Astarion: Oh don't be like that, I'd never want to control you. I love you.
Astarion: That's what you've been waiting to hear, isn't it? That's what you want?
Astarion: We could be together for eternity, ruling this world side by side. We could have it all.
Player: No, this isn't what I want.
Astarion: It seems I misjudged you. I thought we might have a future together - even an eternity - but perhaps you're not worthy.
Astarion: So. What's it to be, darling? Is this it?
Player: I hope we can work things out and stay together.
Astarion: Of course we can. You're the one that I want - the one that I love.
Astarion: And you could be so much more, if you want it. One little bite and you could be mine forever.
Astarion: My dark consort. My right hand. My most beloved spawn.
Player: Spawn? I want to be a true vampire.
Astarion: And you will! All in good time.
Astarion: But we mustn't rush these things. You may need time to adjust.
Astarion: I knew you'd come around.
Astarion: Are you ready, my darling?
Player: I don't want this after all.
Astarion: It seems I misjudged you. I thought we might have a future together - even an eternity - but perhaps you're not worthy.

Astarion: I can't believe you let me do that. Killing all those people.
Astarion: A pleasant surprise.
Player: I wanted what was best for you.
Astarion: You sweet, sweet thing. I want what's best for you too, of course.
Astarion: And one wicked turn deserves another.
Astarion: So, tell me what you desire. What can I do for my dearest pet?
Player: I am not your pet.
Astarion: Oh don't be such a humourless little wretch - it's nothing but a joke.
Player: All right. But if your offer is still open, I want to be a vampire. Just like you.
Astarion: Oh my sweet, there are no vampires like me. And there never will be again.
Astarion: But if you want the gift of eternity, I can certainly offer you that. One little bite is all it would take.
Astarion: It would mean your salvation. Your eternity, despite that thing inside you.
Astarion: That's what you want, isn't it? To be mine? Forever?
Player: So what would I be? A vampire? Or your spawn?
Astarion: You wouldn't just be some spawn - you're far more than that to me.
Astarion: My dark consort. My right hand. My most beloved spawn.
Player: Spawn? I want to be a true vampire.
Astarion: And you will! All in good time.
Astarion: But we mustn't rush these things. You may need time to adjust.
Astarion: I knew you'd come around.
Astarion: Shall we have one last night together before you join me in immortality? One for the road, so to speak.
Player: Huh. I forgot I'd be cold to the touch once I changed...
Astarion: Not having second thoughts, are we?
Player: I don't want this after all.
Astarion: It seems I misjudged you. I thought we might have a future together - even an eternity - but perhaps you're not worthy.
Astarion: So. What's it to be, darling? Is this it?
Player: I hope we can work things out and stay together.
Astarion: Of course we can. You're the one that I want - the one that I love.
Astarion: And you could be so much more, if you want it. One little bite and you could be mine forever.
Astarion: My dark consort. My right hand. My most beloved spawn.
Player: After everything you went through with Cazador, you're going to make me a spawn?
Astarion: Oh that was completely different, I'd never hurt you. I love you.
Astarion: That's what you've been waiting to hear, isn't it? That's what you want?
Astarion: We could be together for eternity, ruling this world side by side. We could have it all.
Player: No, this isn't what I want.
Astarion: It seems I misjudged you. I thought we might have a future together - even an eternity - but perhaps you're not worthy.

Narrator: *You don't sleep well, flitting between dreams and nightmares.*
Narrator: *Maybe you wake up because you know something is wrong. Or maybe you just get lucky.*
Astarion: ...Shit.
NodeContext: Hunched over the player's bedroll, about to bite someone, but they've just woken up and are looking up at you. More deadpan than urgent.
Astarion: No no - it's not what it looks like, I swear!
Astarion: I wasn't going to hurt you! I just needed - well, blood.
Narrator: *There, in dim firelight, you see him for what he really is: a vampire. A slave to sanguine hunger.*
Player: I can't believe I didn't see it - we even found the boar you snacked on.
Astarion: It's not what you think - I'm not some monster!
Astarion: I feed on animals! Boars, deer, kobolds - whatever I can get.
Astarion: I'm just too slow right now. Too weak.
Astarion: If I just had a little blood, I could think clearer. Fight better. Please.
Narrator: *A strange sensation courses through you, and your companion's mind unfolds, secrets half-revealed.*
Player: Push into his mind, searching for the truth.
Astarion: I - what's this? What's happening?
Narrator: *Your mind is full, bursting with ecstasy and terror. Finally, it is coming. You are becoming.*
Narrator: *His mind opens up, revealing cracked and quivering memories. At their heart, you see dark eyes, commanding you to feed.*
Narrator: *You open your mouth and bite down. Not into a tender neck, but into the twisting body of a rat - the only thing your master lets you eat.*
Player: You ate animals because you were forced to. Not because you wanted to.
Astarion: I - yes. Yes, I ate whatever disgusting vermin my master picked. So you can see why I'm slow to trust you.
Astarion: But I do trust you. And you can trust me.
Astarion: No, I needed you to trust me. And you can trust me.
Player: I do. I believe you.
Astarion: Thank you. Do you think you could trust me just a little further?
Astarion: I only need a taste, I swear.
Player: Fine. But not a drop more than you need.
Astarion: Really? I - of course. Not one drop more.
Astarion: Let's make ourselves comfortable, shall we?
NodeContext: Astarion gestures, inviting the player to lie down on the bedroll at his feet.
Narrator: *It's like a shard of ice into your neck - a quick, sharp pain that fades to throbbing numbness. Your breath catches, your pulse quickens.*
Player: Push him back.
Narrator: *You try to push him back, but his grip just gets tighter. You can feel your blood racing, coursing through both your bodies.*
Player: Grab the stake and drive it into his heart.
Astarion: Wretch!
Astarion had been leaning over a prone player, drinking their blood, but they just tried to stab him in the chest. He jumps back, furious.


NodeContext: You've been stabbed, but they missed your heart, so feel free to throw in a grunt of pain

Player: Isobel - Isobel Thorm?
Narrator: *Her breath catches; you notice a barely-perceptible shudder run through her body.*
Isobel: An unfortunate coincidence. I hope never to meet the wicked man who haemorrhaged shadows over this peaceful village. I've heard you might be the person to stop him.
Isobel: A True Soul with a soul. Imagine.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: You seem to have a lot to say about my allegiance. Can we focus on the task at hand?
Isobel: I suppose that would be wise. We have a common enemy, after all: Ketheric Thorm.
Isobel: You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume?
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: Nod. Better to humour her than make an enemy of all in this place. Lady Shar will understand.
Isobel: Refreshingly pragmatic of you. I sense Shar has offered some amount of protection to you already, but... well, no harm in extra precaution - even from a Sel√ªnite.
Player: Ngh... it hurts...
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: The Dark Lady's works aren't for me to question.
Isobel: Mustn't question the great shadow mother, must we?
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I do, though I already have a Moonlantern.
Player: I already have a Moonlantern. I can safely travel the shadows.
Isobel: Well! Now you have two. Just in case.
Isobel: I wish you luck. The very best of it.
Player: Wait - Marcus is a True Soul, you know. And not the good kind, like me.

Raphael: There. Middle-of-somewhere.
Karlach: I don't like this at all.
Player: Can you be more specific than 'somewhere'?
Raphael: The House of Hope. Where the tired come to rest, and the famished come to feed - lavishly.
NodeContext: He spreads his arms as he dramatically introduces this place.
Raphael: Go on. Partake. Enjoy your supper. After all...
Raphael: ...it might just be your last.
Player: I will rise as a kith'rak. Your threats do not worry me.
Raphael: Not easily rattled, I see. Good. Makes the next part that much more straightforward.
Raphael: What's better than a devil you don't know?
Raphael: A devil you do.
Wyll: Hollering hells - you're a cambion.
Raphael: And so much more.
Raphael: Am I a friend? Potentially. An adversary? Conceivably. But a saviour? That's for certain.
Player: Eloquent words, but I'm not seeking another pact.
Raphael: You do not seek it, but it has found you:
Raphael: One skull, two tenants, and no solution in sight.
Raphael: I could fix it all like that.
NodeContext: He snaps his fingers on the word 'that'. As he does so, the candle flames suddenly shine unnaturally bright, bathing the scene in a hellish red glow.
Player: I'll do anything to get rid of the tadpole.

Astarion: I can't believe you let me do that. Killing all those people.
Astarion: A pleasant surprise.
Player: I wanted what was best for you.

Astarion: And one wicked turn deserves another.
Astarion: So, tell me what you desire. What can I do for my dearest pet?
Player: I am not your pet.
Astarion: Oh don't be such a humourless little wretch - it's nothing but a joke.

Astarion: You've earned it.

Astarion: But if you want the gift of eternity, I can certainly offer you that. One little bite is all it would take.
Astarion: It would mean your salvation. Your eternity, despite that thing inside you.
Astarion: That's what you want, isn't it? To be mine? Forever?
Player: What if I don't want forever?
Astarion: What's not to want? We could be together for all time.
Astarion: My dark consort. My right hand. My most beloved spawn.

Astarion: Oh that was completely different, I'd never hurt you. I love you.
Astarion: That's what you've been waiting to hear, isn't it? That's what you want?
Astarion: We could be together for eternity, ruling this world side by side. We could have it all.
Player: No, this isn't what I want.
Astarion: It seems I misjudged you. I thought we might have a future together - even an eternity - but perhaps you're not worthy.
Astarion: So. What's it to be, darling? Is this it?
Player: I hope we can work things out and stay together.

Astarion: And you could be so much more, if you want it. One little bite and you could be mine forever.
Astarion: My dark consort. My right hand. My most beloved spawn.

Astarion: We could be together for eternity, ruling this world side by side. We could have it all.
Player: That does sound appealing...
Astarion: I knew you'd come around.
Astarion: Shall we have one last night together before you join me in immortality? One for the road, so to speak.
Player: Huh. I forgot I'd be cold to the touch once I changed...
Astarion: Not having second thoughts, are we?
Player: I don't want this after all.
Astarion: It seems I misjudged you. I thought we might have a future together - even an eternity - but perhaps you're not worthy.

Narrator: *You don't sleep well, flitting between dreams and nightmares.*
Narrator: *Maybe you wake up because you know something is wrong. Or maybe you just get lucky.*
Astarion: ...Shit.
NodeContext: Hunched over the player's bedroll, about to bite someone, but they've just woken up and are looking up at you. More deadpan than urgent.
Astarion: No no - it's not what it looks like, I swear!
Astarion: I wasn't going to hurt you! I just needed - well, blood.
Narrator: *There, in dim firelight, you see him for what he really is: a vampire. A slave to sanguine hunger.*
Player: I can't believe I didn't see it - we even found the boar you snacked on.
Astarion: It's not what you think - I'm not some monster!
Astarion: I feed on animals! Boars, deer, kobolds - whatever I can get.
Astarion: I'm just too slow right now. Too weak.
Astarion: If I just had a little blood, I could think clearer. Fight better. Please.
Narrator: *A strange sensation courses through you, and your companion's mind unfolds, secrets half-revealed.*
Player: Push into his mind, searching for the truth.
Astarion: I - what's this? What's happening?
Narrator: *A shadow swims across your vision, and a familiar voice tells you to be calm. You are loved.*
Narrator: *His mind opens up, revealing cracked and quivering memories. At their heart, you see dark eyes, commanding you to feed.*
Narrator: *You open your mouth and bite down. Not into a tender neck, but into the twisting body of a rat - the only thing your master lets you eat.*
Player: You ate animals because you were forced to. Not because you wanted to.
Astarion: I - yes. Yes, I ate whatever disgusting vermin my master picked. So you can see why I'm slow to trust you.
Astarion: But I do trust you. And you can trust me.
Astarion: No, I needed you to trust me. And you can trust me.
Player: I do. I believe you.
Astarion: Thank you. Do you think you could trust me just a little further?
Astarion: I only need a taste, I swear.
Player: All right, but go too far and I'll drive a stake through your chest.
Astarion: Ah. Of course. I shall be gentle as a babe.
Astarion: Let's make ourselves comfortable, shall we?
NodeContext: Astarion gestures, inviting the player to lie down on the bedroll at his feet.
Narrator: *It's like a shard of ice into your neck - a quick, sharp pain that fades to throbbing numbness. Your breath catches, your pulse quickens.*
Player: Push him back.
Astarion: Ah! That - that was amazing.
Astarion: My mind is finally clear. I feel strong. I feel... happy!
Player: I don't. That felt wrong.
Astarion: Don't be so dramatic. This is just a little transaction between friends.
Astarion: And look what you've gained. Together, we can take on the world.
Player: You need to leave my camp. Now.

Astarion: I want to thank you.
Player: For what?
Astarion: For what you said while I was in front of that vile drow.
Astarion: I spent two hundred years using my body to lure pretty things back for my Master. What I wanted, how I felt about what I was doing, it never mattered.
Astarion: You could have asked me to do the same - to throw myself at her, what I wanted be damned. But you didn't. And I'm grateful.
Player: I regret stopping you. That potion would've really helped.

Sorn Orlith: What was it like?
Player: I try not to think about it any longer.
Sorn Orlith: My... my apologies for prying.
Sorn Orlith: Pleasure is what I know, and what I do best. Here, I work to create it anew for myself each eve.

Sorn Orlith: I'd have to restrain myself far more than any play-bindings do if I worked in another field. This is a place where I can be myself boundlessly.
Sorn Orlith: There are so many who come to me speaking of a fixation that no one else has ever been able to share with them... and never will again.
Sorn Orlith: A once-in-a-lifetime moment of passion. Every day. What could be better? Don't you want to try it?

Gale: Well I suppose it would do no good to back out now. Let us begin this little anthropological study, if we must.
Player: No, Halsin! Tame yourself!

Wulbren Bongle: Good to see you. Wasn't sure you'd make it to the city. Regretting it yet?
Wulbren Bongle: I spent a lot of time thinking of worst case scenarios while I was locked in that cell you plucked me out of at Moonrise.
Wulbren Bongle: I didn't imagine anything as bad as this. The Gondians have handed Enver Gortash the means to bring about the end of liberty in Baldur's Gate.
Wulbren Bongle: And the citizens have rolled out the red carpet for their new tyrant.
Wulbren Bongle: Resistance fighters are few and far between - my Ironhands, what's left of the Harpers, and you. I hope.
Player: I'm with you.
Wulbren Bongle: Good. We don't have a chance unless we stick together - not while the Gondians' metal monsters are patrolling the streets.
Wulbren Bongle: The Steel Watch. They're a threat to you, me - and every man, woman and child in the city.
Wulbren Bongle: They act all civilised... servants of the people. But they only serve one man.
Wulbren Bongle: When he becomes Grand Duke, it will only get worse. Laws will change, freedoms will vanish, and soon you'll be accused and sentenced before you've even committed a crime.
Wulbren Bongle: And the fucking Gondians are to blame for all of it.
Player: Perhaps the Gondians were infected with a tadpole?
Wulbren Bongle: Perhaps. All the more reason to get rid of them.
Wulbren Bongle: They invented the Steel Watchers. And they're building an army of them.
Wulbren Bongle: They've always been happy to provide their technology to despots in exchange for a stipend and the freedom to work in peace.
Wulbren Bongle: They would have licked Sarevok's boots given the chance, and now they'll kiss Gortash's ring while the city screams.
Wulbren Bongle: I had a plan to put a stop to them. But the way things are now, if we stick our heads above ground, the Watchers are on us like flies on shit.
Player: What was the plan?
Wulbren Bongle: Same as it always is. Eliminate the threat.
Wulbren Bongle: In this case - the foundry where these atrocities are produced.
Wulbren Bongle: The Gondians are ingenious. But we're more than equal to them - there's nothing they can build that the Ironhands can't tear down.
Wulbren Bongle: I've built something unique for just that purpose.
Wulbren Bongle: A runepowder bomb - first of its kind. Fifty wizards high on the Weave couldn't summon this kind of firepower.
Wulbren Bongle: Get the bomb inside the Gondian facility, and - boom. Problem solved.
Barcus Wroot: Wulbren, please. This is too far! Everyone in the foundry would be killed.
Wulbren Bongle: Quiet, Barcus. The adults are talking.
Player: This plan seems a bit loud for my liking. Messy, too.
Barcus Wroot: That's what I've been saying! There may yet be a peaceful solution.
Wulbren Bongle: Fine. You want to try flapping your gums in the belly of the beast, be my guest.
Wulbren Bongle: But their idea of diplomacy is a steel fist shoved where the sun don't shine.
Wulbren Bongle: So take the bomb. Just in case I'm right, and you're wrong.
Player: Keep your bomb. I'm doing this my way.

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help.
Jaheira: The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation.
Jaheira: We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.
Player: Ketheric Thorm. He and I have history.
Jaheira: You were the one who rescued those the Absolute had imprisoned. You were courageous to brave the depths of Ketheric's stronghold.
Jaheira: I suppose you know about Ketheric, then. His invincibility. That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed.
Jaheira: We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter.
Jaheira: He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope.
Jaheira: You are that hope.
Player: I'm trying my best to be...
Jaheira: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul.
Jaheira: Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage.
Jaheira: Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.
Player: There's something you should know - Marcus, the Flaming Fist upstairs, is a True Soul. He wants to kidnap Isobel.

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help.
Jaheira: The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation.
Jaheira: We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.
Player: Ketheric Thorm. He and I have history.
Jaheira: You were the one who rescued those the Absolute had imprisoned. You were courageous to brave the depths of Ketheric's stronghold.
Jaheira: I suppose you know about Ketheric, then. His invincibility. That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed.
Jaheira: We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter.
Jaheira: He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope.
Jaheira: You are that hope.
Player: I'm trying my best to be...
Jaheira: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul.
Jaheira: Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage.
Jaheira: Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.
Player: There's something you should know - Marcus, the Flaming Fist upstairs, is a True Soul. He wants to kidnap Isobel.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Jaheir takes the glass from the table.
Jaheira: This place is crawling with Harpers. If Marcus managed to get himself infected, we would've known the same minute.
Jaheira: Is this some kind of test? Or a game, perhaps?
Player: I have proof, if you'll just come upstairs and look.
Jaheira: A Harper's gaze can only be turned by proof. By the looks of it, a tall tale is all you have to offer.
Jaheira: It doesn't spoil the taste, if that's what you're wondering.
Player: I prefer using Venian's Breath for interrogations - it doesn't carry a scent.
Jaheira: Not, but it does leave the subject paralysed. Whatever comes after, I would have you standing on your own two feet.
Player: Drink the wine.

Raphael: Do you know what happens when a devil is struck down on this charming plane of existence?
Raphael: It returns to the hells - to the very point where it last stood before venturing to whichever devilforsaken plane it died on.
Raphael: In the case of our friend Yurgir, the orthon you so handily dispatched in the temple of Shar, he manifested in my House of Hope.
Raphael: He returned to me chastened but intact, his wounds healed, his body restored.
Raphael: He thought I would dismember him but he has his uses so instead I am reeducating him.
Astarion: We delivered the devil. Now I want what I'm owed - we had a deal.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: We had a deal - the orthon for information.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: We had a deal - the orthon for information.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: We had a deal - the orthon for information.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: Spill it - this sounds fascinating.
Astarion: I'd appreciate a little less enthusiasm when it comes to Cazador and his horrors.
Raphael: Oh come, Astarion. We're about to unveil your destiny - you should be quivering in anticipation.
Raphael: Carved into that ivory skin of yours is one part of an infernal contract between the archdevil Mephistopheles and your former master, Cazador Szarr.
Raphael: In full, the contract states that Cazador will be granted knowledge of an infernal ritual so vile it has never been performed.
Raphael: The Rite of Profane Ascension.
Raphael: It promises to be a marvellous ceremony. Very elaborate, incredibly ancient, and entirely diabolical.
Raphael: If he completes the rite, he will become a new kind of being - the Vampire Ascendant.
Raphael: All the strengths of his vampiric form will be amplified, and alongside them he will enjoy the luxuries of the living.
Raphael: The arousals and appetites of man will return to him, and unlike Astarion, he will have no need of a parasite to protect him from the sun.
Raphael: But the ritual has its price, as all worthwhile things do. Lord Cazador will need to sacrifice a number of souls, including all of his vampiric spawn, if he is to ascend.
Raphael: Imagine how he felt, then, when one of those precious spawn simply disappeared into thin air.
Raphael: The only missing ingredient is Astarion.
Raphael: You are the final piece he requires to complete the ritual - your scars bind you to it. Your soul will set off a very wave of death, bringing Cazador his twisted life.
Raphael: And that, my tragic and toothsome friend, is that. Now if you'll excuse me, I have business elsewhere.
NodeContext: [Tarik] snaps fingers at the end of the line.
Astarion: Hmm...
Player: Cazador is a piece of shit. We're going to stop him.
Astarion: Do you think it's so simple?
Astarion: What do you think I should do?
Player: You'll never be free while Cazador lives.
Astarion: I hate how right you are.
Astarion: I knew he wouldn't leave me alone even when I was just another wretched toy for him to play with.
Astarion: But if I'm the key to this power he craves, he'll hunt me to the ends of Faer√ªn.
Astarion: I need to take the fight to him.
Astarion: And I need you to help me.
Player: After we dealt with our tadpole problem, yes, I'll help you then.
Astarion: Once we deal with the tadpole, I'll be back to my nocturnal self. When you're being hunted by vampires, the dark is the worst place to hide.
Astarion: I need to deal with Cazador while I still have any kind of advantage over him.
Astarion: If you won't risk taking him on for my sake, think of the innocent souls he'll sacrifice in this ritual.
Player: The Absolute is a greater threat - we need to focus.

Astarion: Well hello. Welcome to my humble party.
Astarion: What's your poison? Red? White?
Player: Just water.
Astarion: Your funeral.
Astarion: So, what are we drinking to? Other than a pile of corpses.
NodeContext: Pouring you a drink. You both pick up your cups.
Player: That's not funny.
Astarion: Oh don't be so sour - it's a party.
Astarion: You did what you had to. Don't be ashamed that you did it well.
Player: It was more a mountain of corpses than a pile...
Astarion: Ha! All right, to a mountain of corpses!
NodeContext: Toasts and drinks
Astarion: Mmm. Delicious.
Astarion: So. What happens next?
Player: I'd hoped to get close to you, but I don't want to light you on fire.
Player: Well, I'd planned to bed you...
Player: Well, I'd planned to bed you...
Astarion: Does Lae'zel know that? I saw how she looked at you earlier.
Astarion: I'd hate to get between the gith and her trophy. No, I think we'll end this evening as friends.
Player: Are you offering anything better? Because I could be persuaded...
Astarion: Let's wait until things quieten down a bit. Once the others are asleep, we'll find each other.
Player: On second thought, maybe we'd better not.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: Glad I could be of help.
Halsin: I must admit, I didn't expect anyone would come to my aid. Who in their right mind would infiltrate a goblin infested temple. Unless...
Halsin: ...Hrrm. That look in your eyes - I've seen it before. Are you feeling all right?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what‚Äôs inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I think this artefact has something to do with it.
Halsin: Hmmm... that looks very alien. As alien as the mind flayers. They do not belong on this world.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: So all of this was for nothing.
Halsin: Patience. I can't just snap my fingers... but I know where the solution almost certainly lies.
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: You seem to know a lot about this. Will you come with me to Moonrise?
Halsin: I wish I could, but there's still work I've yet to finish - blood I've yet to spill.
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Kagha was swayed by Shadow Druids. She nearly sealed the grove.
Halsin: Kagha... I should have suspected she'd take things too far. I'll deal with her when I can.
Halsin: But there are other matters to attend to before that.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: It's too late to merely kill this horde's leadership - their forces are already marching. If you want me to help, you need to help me first.
Halsin: You must get ahead of them, muster the defences.
Player: Very well. I'll go rescue the grove.

Havkelaag: Ah, a fellow inhabitor of the Underdark.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to our subterranean home: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You're letting your personal biases affect your method. Why assume they're evil?
Havkelaag: I assume nothing. Innate githyanki cruelty is an established fact - no doubt you witnessed it yourself in the retrieval of the egg itself.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: Why follow the dogma of a draconic god?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: An experiment like this will only confirm the surface dwellers' suspicion of us.
Havkelaag: Of course it won't. If anything, it will do quite the opposite. The academic institutions up here will finally be forced to take us seriously.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

Yurgir: What's this? Fresh entertainment.

Yurgir: You can't help. It's not just walls that keep me here. Not the traps, the dark or the creatures it hides. Something stronger holds me - a contract.
Yurgir: Either I fulfil the contract, die trying... or forfeit my freedom. If I leave this place now, I'll become Raphael's slave.

Yurgir: I spent a century roaming these halls - I spilled every drop of Dark Justiciar blood that there was to spill. And you think you can do better?

Disciple Z'rell: The facts suggest otherwise. You were ordered to retrieve the artefact - you failed to do so.
Sazza: We did as you lot told us. Minthara's the one who -
Disciple Z'rell: Enough!
NodeContext: Via mind meld
Narrator: *A blast of mental energy washes over you, filling the room. Your tadpole squirms, urging you to obey.*
Disciple Z'rell: You failed to retrieve the artefact. You failed to protect your True Soul. You do not deserve to live.
Player: Don't kill them! They're loyal followers of the Absolute.
Player: Hear, hear!
Narrator: *As the General's attention shifts to you, a memory stirs - a memory of this room, and his voice raised in anger.*
Player: Hear, hear!
Ketheric Thorm: Ah, the True Soul who delivered a grove of non-believers into the Absolute's arms.
Fezzerk: You know I'm loyal, tell 'im -
Disciple Z'rell: Silence!
Ketheric Thorm: True Soul. You have seen these goblins at work, have you not? What say you?
NodeContext: Almost bored with the proceedings. Wanting to fob off judgement to someone else. He's thisclose to getting his daughter back; punishing goblins doesn't interest him.
Player: Death is probably too good for them.
Ketheric Thorm: Alas, it's the best option we have.
Sazza: No - mercy!
Ketheric Thorm: Kill them. Quickly.
NodeContext: Standing up to leave
Ketheric Thorm: Kill the goblins, too.
NodeContext: An afterthought, as he stands up to leave
Sazza: What? No!
Drenn: You creaking old bag of shit!
NodeContext: Drenn grabs a halberd from a surprised guard and throws it at Ketheric.

NodeContext: KETHERIC stares at the halberd embedded in his chest in shock. Then, after a beat, he grunts in anger and pain as with one hand he grabs the halberd and pulls it free. The wound left by the blade is just a glowing purple gash, which disappears before our eyes, leaving his chest without even a scratch.
Disciple Z'rell: I'm so sorry, my lord. She's an unbeliever - outside my control.
NodeContext: Very apologetic - this should never have happened
Ketheric Thorm: Try again.
NodeContext: Ketheric drops the halberd on the ground and challenges the goblin.
Ketheric Thorm: Huh.
NodeContext: Just been stabbed, but is invulnerable.
Drenn: No - NO!
NodeContext: terrified - you know you're about to die
Ketheric Thorm: Dispose of the rest as you see fit.
Ketheric Thorm: Or better yet - let us take advantage of our surprising guest, and their particular creative genius.
Ketheric Thorm: I'm sure the results will send a clear message to the troops on the importance of discipline.
Disciple Z'rell: Of course, my lord. Thank you.

Disciple Z'rell: Here, in the seat of the Absolute's power, your authority over them is complete. They will obey any command.
Disciple Z'rell: Report to me upstairs when you're done.
Sazza: You wouldn't hurt me, would you? We're mates, me and you. Practically family!
Player: I'll give you a fair chance. Fight me - you either die, or you kill me and you're free to go.

Gauntlet Edwynna: State your business.

GROUP_SteelWatchers: You are marked for special treatment. Not simply an enemy of the people, but an enemy of the Absolute. Come quietly, or die.

He Who Was: Madeline's spirit is within reach. It is time to make her face trial, to make her suffer.
He Who Was: And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: I'd like to hear her story first - I imagine it's quite the tale.
He Who Was: Careful - for a serpent in life is a serpent in death.
He Who Was: Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: You 'didn't mean' to kill your friends? How laughable.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining.
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: Don't blame others for what you did.
Madeline: You didn't see it. Didn't see what the Dark Justiciar did.
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.
Madeline: She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Anything? Then hurt yourself as Ben and Marc did - stab yourself.
Madeline: Like... this?
NodeContext: Madeline draws a blade from behind her and holds it in front of her stomach, blade pointed towards her stomach. She is utterly terrified (pose like seppuku)
Player: Start stabbing, and don't stop until I say so.
Madeline: Ah! I'm sorry.
NodeContext: Ah! is a noise of pain as she stabs herself in the stomach and then pulls out the knife. 'I'm sorry' is said in clear pain.
Madeline: Argh. I'm so sorry.
NodeContext: stabs herself again on 'Argh', noise of pain. I'm so so sorry is half crying as she's in agony.
Player: Stop. You've done enough.

GROUP_SHA_LastJusticiar_Rats: Remember your word - spare us, leave this place. Your reward awaits.
GROUP_SHA_LastJusticiar_Rats: Every little death fills my head with more thoughts. It's too much - too painful. Kill one more of us, and you will pay.
Player: You're no ordinary rat, are you? None of you are.
GROUP_SHA_LastJusticiar_Rats: An ordinary rat alone. But together? Something more.
GROUP_SHA_LastJusticiar_Rats: Some remember turning away from the sun. Some remember donning a black cloak. Some remember plunging a blade into an innocent heart.
GROUP_SHA_LastJusticiar_Rats: But we all remember a name. Lyrthindor. We share who he was.

Havkelaag: Well met. What can the Society of Brilliance do for you?
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You yourself have no doubt experienced the prejudice of those who assume that, as beings of the Underdark, we are inherently evil.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: So the child inside will be experimented on?
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: So you, too, follow the teachings of Bahamut. Why him?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: No benefit could justify you inflicting such cruelty.
Havkelaag: Rigorous experimental methods demand we do not indulge our own emotional responses in the application of discomfort to our subjects.
Havkelaag: Only by the full, uninhibited application of psionic stimuli will we have a true measure of whether the child's innate evil has been cured.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

Wulbren Bongle: Good to see you. Wasn't sure you'd make it to the city. Regretting it yet?
Wulbren Bongle: I spent a lot of time thinking of worst case scenarios while I was locked in that cell you plucked me out of at Moonrise.
Wulbren Bongle: I didn't imagine anything as bad as this. The Gondians have handed Enver Gortash the means to bring about the end of liberty in Baldur's Gate.
Wulbren Bongle: And the citizens have rolled out the red carpet for their new tyrant.
Wulbren Bongle: Resistance fighters are few and far between - my Ironhands, what's left of the Harpers, and you. I hope.
Player: I'm with you.
Wulbren Bongle: Good. We don't have a chance unless we stick together - not while the Gondians' metal monsters are patrolling the streets.
Wulbren Bongle: The Steel Watch. They're a threat to you, me - and every man, woman and child in the city.
Wulbren Bongle: They act all civilised... servants of the people. But they only serve one man.
Wulbren Bongle: When he becomes Grand Duke, it will only get worse. Laws will change, freedoms will vanish, and soon you'll be accused and sentenced before you've even committed a crime.
Wulbren Bongle: And the fucking Gondians are to blame for all of it.
Player: Cheer up Wulbren. We're here to help.
Wulbren Bongle: I heard about that. You had the Harpers all excited, but there aren't many Harpers left.
Wulbren Bongle: These Steel Watchers. One of them is the equivalent of a red dragon. An army of them, well... there's never been an army of dragons.
Player: I'm not scared of dragons. Or Steel Watchers.
Wulbren Bongle: There's a line where bravery becomes stupidity. You just crossed it.
Wulbren Bongle: Scared or not, you can't take down every Steel Watcher in the city. Unless you hit the people who build them - the Gondians.
Wulbren Bongle: They've always been happy to provide their technology to despots in exchange for a stipend and the freedom to work in peace.
Wulbren Bongle: They would have licked Sarevok's boots given the chance, and now they'll kiss Gortash's ring while the city screams.
Wulbren Bongle: I had a plan to put a stop to them. But the way things are now, if we stick our heads above ground, the Watchers are on us like flies on shit.
Player: No plan survives contact with the enemy - unless I'm involved.
Wulbren Bongle: Exactly. You freed us from Ketheric's rotten cells - I reckon you can rid us of these Gondians just as easily.
Wulbren Bongle: You just need a little assistance, and I can provide it.
Wulbren Bongle: The Gondians are ingenious. But we're more than equal to them - there's nothing they can build that the Ironhands can't tear down.
Wulbren Bongle: I've built something unique for just that purpose.
Wulbren Bongle: A runepowder bomb - first of its kind. Fifty wizards high on the Weave couldn't summon this kind of firepower.
Wulbren Bongle: Get the bomb inside the Gondian facility, and - boom. Problem solved.
Barcus Wroot: Wulbren, please. This is too far! Everyone in the foundry would be killed.
Wulbren Bongle: Quiet, Barcus. The adults are talking.
Player: Barcus has a point - this sounds like mass murder.
Wulbren Bongle: It's liberation.
Wulbren Bongle: The Gondians picked their side the minute they took orders from Gortash.
Wulbren Bongle: If they had any courage, they'd have refused him and died like heroes, spitting in his face.
Wulbren Bongle: Now they'll die like the dogs they are.
Player: I'll make contact with the Gondians - maybe they'll see reason.
Barcus Wroot: That's what I've been saying! There may yet be a peaceful solution.
Wulbren Bongle: Fine. You want to try flapping your gums in the belly of the beast, be my guest.
Wulbren Bongle: But their idea of diplomacy is a steel fist shoved where the sun don't shine.
Wulbren Bongle: So take the bomb. Just in case I'm right, and you're wrong.
Player: Keep your bomb. I'm doing this my way.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: shot of player and whatever remaining gnomes are alive panting, catching their breath. Wulbren appears and claps slowly
Wulbren Bongle: That was a hell of a show, my friend. Watchers collapse in the street as we speak, and the Foundry?
Wulbren Bongle: The scent of runepowder drifts through the city like a warm embrace - I see my bomb did the trick.
Wulbren Bongle: Watchers collapse in the street as we speak. The city thanks you - I thank you.
Wulbren Bongle: But it's not over - so long as a single parasitic Gondian remains, Baldur's Gate is under threat.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Wulbren, enough. The Gondians are no more - I am all that is left. You've won.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Take the city - let the Ironhands reign supreme. I just wish to go home and mourn my daughter in peace.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Take the city - let the Ironhands reign supreme. I just wish to go home, and to hold my daughter.
Player: What about Gortash? What if he forces you to build up his Steel Watch once more?

("safe houses" as in "safehouses" for shelter)
Wulbren Bongle: Please - if a Gondian told me the sky was blue, I'd look outside and check.
Wulbren Bongle: You Gondians will lie, scheme, and torment this city until your dying breaths. Let's end this.
NodeContext: the mask has truly gone, we see wulbren for what he is - cruel, spiteful and viscious

Barcus Wroot: Kill the Gondians, and you kill all we love: Collaboration. Challenge. Solving problems with the power of reason, creativity, and invention.
Barcus Wroot: I still want to believe you're better than that, Wulbren. But even I am having my doubts.

Varsh Ko'kuu: You can tell Kith'rak Therezzyn that my position has not changed: the egg requires more time. Furthermore - oh.
NodeContext: You turn on 'Furthermore' expecting to see an angry guard, but you're surprised to find the player - a complete stranger.
Varsh Ko'kuu: You are not from Cr√®che Y'llek. What are you doing here?
Varsh Ko'kuu: Of course, a stranger from a strange cr√®che may have different customs. What brings you here?
Player: I wanted to see the hatchery. I didn't expect it to look so empty.
Varsh Ko'kuu: Almost all of the eggs in this clutch have hatched. We await only one more, which is... taking its time.
Lae'zel: Failure at the first hurdle of existence. Most caretakers would crush it and be done.
Varsh Ko'kuu: Most caretakers would not give the child its fair chance, but I shall. There could be greatness in that shell.
Narrator: *You note that the hope in his voice is tinged with weariness. It's the voice of a man who's fought the inevitable for a long time.*
Player: Tell me the truth. Why do you really care about this one so much?
Varsh Ko'kuu: Not all that arrive late are weak. I created this entire hatchery, despite being the last of my clutch to hatch.
Varsh Ko'kuu: They almost drowned me in the hatching pool. If it wasn't for the varsh of my clutch -
Varsh Ko'kuu: This one deserves the same chance.
Player: Let me help - I can take it somewhere safe.

Havkelaag: I say - that wasn't a githyanki egg you were fiddling around with, was it?
Havkelaag: How would you like to sell it to the Society of Brilliance? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: So the child inside will be experimented on?
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: Why follow the dogma of a draconic god?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: No benefit could justify you inflicting such cruelty.
Havkelaag: Rigorous experimental methods demand we do not indulge our own emotional responses in the application of discomfort to our subjects.
Havkelaag: Only by the full, uninhibited application of psionic stimuli will we have a true measure of whether the child's innate evil has been cured.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

Raphael: Do you know what happens when a devil is struck down on this charming plane of existence?
Raphael: It returns to the hells - to the very point where it last stood before venturing to whichever devilforsaken plane it died on.
Raphael: In the case of our friend Yurgir, the orthon you so handily dispatched in the temple of Shar, he manifested in my House of Hope.
Raphael: He returned to me chastened but intact, his wounds healed, his body restored.
Raphael: He thought I would dismember him but he has his uses so instead I am reeducating him.
Astarion: We delivered the devil. Now I want what I'm owed - we had a deal.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.

Astarion: Even if I wanted to walk away from all of this, I can't. Cazador won't let me.
Raphael: And why would he want to walk away? This is his destiny.
Raphael: As you know already, your precious skin is home to one part of a contract between the archdevil Mephistopheles, and your former master, Cazador Szarr.
Raphael: In full, the contract states that Cazador will be granted knowledge of an infernal ritual so vile it has never been performed.
Raphael: The Rite of Profane Ascension.
Raphael: It promises to be a marvellous ceremony. Very elaborate, incredibly ancient, and entirely diabolical.
Raphael: If he completes the rite, he will become a new kind of being - the Vampire Ascendant.
Raphael: All the strengths of his vampiric form will be amplified, and alongside them he will enjoy the luxuries of the living.
Raphael: The arousals and appetites of man will return to him, and unlike Astarion, he will have no need of a parasite to protect him from the sun.
Raphael: But the ritual has its price, as all worthwhile things do. Lord Cazador will need to sacrifice a number of souls, including all of his vampiric spawn, if he is to ascend.
Raphael: Imagine how he felt, then, when one of those precious spawn simply disappeared into thin air.
Raphael: The only missing ingredient is Astarion.
Raphael: You are the final piece he requires to complete the ritual - your scars bind you to it. Your soul will set off a very wave of death, bringing Cazador his twisted life.
Raphael: And that, my tragic and toothsome friend, is that. Now if you'll excuse me, I have business elsewhere.

Raphael: Do you know what happens when a devil is struck down on this charming plane of existence?
Raphael: It returns to the hells - to the very point where it last stood before venturing to whichever devilforsaken plane it died on.
Raphael: In the case of our friend Yurgir, the orthon you so handily dispatched in the temple of Shar, he manifested in my House of Hope.
Raphael: He returned to me chastened but intact, his wounds healed, his body restored.
Raphael: He thought I would dismember him but he has his uses so instead I am reeducating him.
Astarion: We delivered the devil. Now I want what I'm owed - we had a deal.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: We had a deal - the orthon for information.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: Are you sure you want to know, Astarion? Maybe it's best left in the past.
Astarion: Even if I wanted to walk away from all of this, I can't. Cazador won't let me.
Raphael: And why would he want to walk away? This is his destiny.
Raphael: As you know already, your precious skin is home to one part of a contract between the archdevil Mephistopheles, and your former master, Cazador Szarr.
Raphael: In full, the contract states that Cazador will be granted knowledge of an infernal ritual so vile it has never been performed.
Raphael: The Rite of Profane Ascension.
Raphael: It promises to be a marvellous ceremony. Very elaborate, incredibly ancient, and entirely diabolical.
Raphael: If he completes the rite, he will become a new kind of being - the Vampire Ascendant.
Raphael: All the strengths of his vampiric form will be amplified, and alongside them he will enjoy the luxuries of the living.
Raphael: The arousals and appetites of man will return to him, and unlike you, he will have no need of a parasite to protect him from the sun.
Raphael: But the ritual has its price, as all worthwhile things do. Lord Cazador will need to sacrifice a number of souls, including all of his vampiric spawn, if he is to ascend.
Raphael: Imagine how he felt, then, when one of those precious spawn simply disappeared into thin air.
Raphael: The only missing ingredient is Astarion.
Raphael: You are the final piece he requires to complete the ritual - your scars bind you to it. Your soul will set off a very wave of death, bringing Cazador his twisted life.
Raphael: And that, my tragic and toothsome friend, is that. Now if you'll excuse me, I have business elsewhere.

Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to the Underdark: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her.
Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You yourself have no doubt experienced the prejudice of those who assume that, as beings of the Underdark, we are inherently evil.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: What does this 'intellectually stimulating' upbringing look like?
Havkelaag: In the literal sense, I will need to induce the egg to hatch via the application of certain currents to the creature inside.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: So you, too, follow the teachings of Bahamut. Why him?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Your findings are irrelevant, as are the opinions of all on this kaincha plane.
Havkelaag: Ah. A display of the well-known githyanki arrogance. I am not sure my experiment can cure that particular affliction, but give me time and I will find a way.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

Astarion: You know, I was just thinking about you. Remembering our little encounter in the night.

Astarion: Not that anyone's volunteered, it's just an idle fancy.

Astarion: I don't think they'd volunteer, of course, but it doesn't make me any less curious.

Astarion: But the gith? What in the hells would she taste like?

Astarion: Still, I am intrigued by the possibilities...

Oskar Fevras: Wait, WAIT! I'm just a prisoner - spare me and there'll be coin, I swear it!
NodeContext: Panicked, he just saw us kill a lot of people and thinks we're about to kill him
Player: Who are you?
Oskar Fevras: I'm an artist. These faithless bastards were trying to ransom me back to my patron.
Oskar Fevras: She's a woman of great means - and great generosity to those who serve her well.
Oskar Fevras: Heroes who rescue her prize painter, for example. Oskar Fevras, at your service.
Oskar Fevras: Well, you should at least know what you've paid for. I am the Oskar Fevras, at your service.
Player: I am the [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53], at yours.
Oskar Fevras: A genuine pleasure. I'm in your debt - as is my patron. My betrothed, I should say.
Oskar Fevras: Assuming Lady Jannath still wishes to marry after our little... falling out.
Player: Who is Lady Jannath?
Oskar Fevras: A noblewoman of passion, refinement and, as it turns out, quite ferocious temper.
Oskar Fevras: The latter I learned only after the engagement, when I told her I was in love with someone else.
Oskar Fevras: I made a timely retreat into the countryside. To paint, and clear my head. To choose, I suppose.
Player: A truly horrifying dilemma.
Oskar Fevras: Indeed - one to split the very soul. But I dare not dwell on it any longer lest I weep.
Oskar Fevras: And we have your reward to consider - once I have made my way safely back to the city.
Oskar Fevras: Say - I don't suppose you could spare some coin, could you? Ease the discomforts of the road some?
Player: I can spare a little. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

Raphael: Do you know what happens when a devil is struck down on this charming plane of existence?
Raphael: It returns to the hells - to the very point where it last stood before venturing to whichever devilforsaken plane it died on.
Raphael: In the case of our friend Yurgir, the orthon you so handily dispatched in the temple of Shar, he manifested in my House of Hope.
Raphael: He returned to me chastened but intact, his wounds healed, his body restored.
Raphael: He thought I would dismember him but he has his uses so instead I am reeducating him.
Astarion: We delivered the devil. Now I want what I'm owed - we had a deal.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: We had a deal - the orthon for information.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: We had a deal - the orthon for information.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: Spill it - this sounds fascinating.
Astarion: I'd appreciate a little less enthusiasm when it comes to Cazador and his horrors.
Raphael: Oh come, Astarion. We're about to unveil your destiny - you should be quivering in anticipation.
Raphael: As you know already, your precious skin is home to one part of a contract between the archdevil Mephistopheles, and your former master, Cazador Szarr.
Raphael: In full, the contract states that Cazador will be granted knowledge of an infernal ritual so vile it has never been performed.
Raphael: The Rite of Profane Ascension.
Raphael: It promises to be a marvellous ceremony. Very elaborate, incredibly ancient, and entirely diabolical.
Raphael: If he completes the rite, he will become a new kind of being - the Vampire Ascendant.
Raphael: All the strengths of his vampiric form will be amplified, and alongside them he will enjoy the luxuries of the living.
Raphael: The arousals and appetites of man will return to him, and unlike you, he will have no need of a parasite to protect him from the sun.
Raphael: But the ritual has its price, as all worthwhile things do. Lord Cazador will need to sacrifice a number of souls, including all of his vampiric spawn, if he is to ascend.
Raphael: Imagine how he felt, then, when one of those precious spawn simply disappeared into thin air.
Raphael: The only missing ingredient is Astarion.
Raphael: You are the final piece he requires to complete the ritual - your scars bind you to it. Your soul will set off a very wave of death, bringing Cazador his twisted life.
Raphael: And that, my tragic and toothsome friend, is that. Now if you'll excuse me, I have business elsewhere.
NodeContext: [Tarik] snaps fingers at the end of the line.
Astarion: Hmm...
Player: Cazador is a piece of shit. We're going to stop him.
Astarion: Do you think it's so simple?
Astarion: What do you think I should do?
Player: I think you should run. If Cazador can't find you, he can't complete his ritual.

Astarion: How long do you think I can run? He has eternity to find me.
Astarion: He'll never leave me alone. I didn't think he would when I was just one more wretched toy for him to play with.
Astarion: But if I'm the key to this power he craves, he'll hunt me to the ends of Faer√ªn.
Astarion: I need to take the fight to him.
Astarion: And I need you to help me.
Player: After we dealt with our tadpole problem, yes, I'll help you then.
Astarion: Once we deal with the tadpole, I'll be back to my nocturnal self. When you're being hunted by vampires, the dark is the worst place to hide.
Astarion: I need to deal with Cazador while I still have any kind of advantage over him.
Astarion: If you won't risk taking him on for my sake, think of the innocent souls he'll sacrifice in this ritual.
Player: We're done talking about this, Astarion. My decision is made.

Lunkbug: Oh Beldron... I'm so sorry. I'll get you out of there. I promise.
Player: I have news: half the trapped gnomes are already dead.
Lunkbug: Great gods. How - how could you know that?
Player: I spoke with their ghosts. Chatty folks, all in all.
Apprentice Laridda: Ghosts? N-no. That can't be. This must be a joke.
Lunkbug: Damn it, Laridda. We've lost enough of us. I'm not losing Beldron, too.
Lunkbug: Hear me out - our friends are trapped in the cave-in. And I know a way to get them out.

Player: Fear not, gnome. I will protect you. Tell me what you know.
Apprentice Laridda: I - all right. Go ahead, Lunkbug. Tell her.
Lunkbug: A few days back, there was a... a scene. Our friend Philomeen, she's a sapper. Set off a blast and ran off.
Lunkbug: We set a spot for hiding if someone found trouble. I'll mark your map.
Lunkbug: If Philomeen made it, you'll find her there. She'll have the stuff to blow that tunnel wide open and get Beldron and the rest out.
Shadowheart: Sounds like an unnecessary risk to me. Though that hasn't stopped us before.
Player: I'll do what I can.

Raphael: Do you know what happens when a devil is struck down on this charming plane of existence?
Raphael: It returns to the hells - to the very point where it last stood before venturing to whichever devilforsaken plane it died on.
Raphael: In the case of our friend Yurgir, the orthon you so handily dispatched in the temple of Shar, he manifested in my House of Hope.
Raphael: He returned to me chastened but intact, his wounds healed, his body restored.
Raphael: He thought I would dismember him but he has his uses so instead I am reeducating him.
Astarion: We delivered the devil. Now I want what I'm owed - we had a deal.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: Spill it - this sounds fascinating.
Astarion: I'd appreciate a little less enthusiasm when it comes to Cazador and his horrors.
Raphael: Oh come, Astarion. We're about to unveil your destiny - you should be quivering in anticipation.
Raphael: As you know already, your precious skin is home to one part of a contract between the archdevil Mephistopheles, and your former master, Cazador Szarr.
Raphael: In full, the contract states that Cazador will be granted knowledge of an infernal ritual so vile it has never been performed.
Raphael: The Rite of Profane Ascension.
Raphael: It promises to be a marvellous ceremony. Very elaborate, incredibly ancient, and entirely diabolical.
Raphael: If he completes the rite, he will become a new kind of being - the Vampire Ascendant.
Raphael: All the strengths of his vampiric form will be amplified, and alongside them he will enjoy the luxuries of the living.
Raphael: The arousals and appetites of man will return to him, and unlike you, he will have no need of a parasite to protect him from the sun.
Raphael: But the ritual has its price, as all worthwhile things do. Lord Cazador will need to sacrifice a number of souls, including all of his vampiric spawn, if he is to ascend.
Raphael: Imagine how he felt, then, when one of those precious spawn simply disappeared into thin air.
Raphael: The only missing ingredient is Astarion.
Raphael: You are the final piece he requires to complete the ritual - your scars bind you to it. Your soul will set off a very wave of death, bringing Cazador his twisted life.
Raphael: And that, my tragic and toothsome friend, is that. Now if you'll excuse me, I have business elsewhere.
NodeContext: [Tarik] snaps fingers at the end of the line.
Astarion: Hmm...
Player: 'Hmm'? That's all you have to say?
Astarion: I was... contemplating. It's a lot to take in.
Astarion: What do you think I should do?
Player: You'll never be free while Cazador lives.
Astarion: I hate how right you are.
Astarion: I knew he wouldn't leave me alone even when I was just another wretched toy for him to play with.
Astarion: But if I'm the key to this power he craves, he'll hunt me to the ends of Faer√ªn.
Astarion: I need to take the fight to him.
Astarion: And I need you to help me.
Player: If he comes for you, I'll defend you. But we're not risking an attack on his lair.
Astarion: If you won't risk taking him on for my sake, think of the innocent souls he'll sacrifice in this ritual.
Player: The Absolute is a greater threat - we need to focus.

Varsh Ko'kuu: They almost drowned me in the hatching pool. If it wasn't for the varsh of my clutch -
Varsh Ko'kuu: This one deserves the same chance.

Raphael: Do you know what happens when a devil is struck down on this charming plane of existence?
Raphael: It returns to the hells - to the very point where it last stood before venturing to whichever devilforsaken plane it died on.
Raphael: In the case of our friend Yurgir, the orthon you so handily dispatched in the temple of Shar, he manifested in my House of Hope.
Raphael: He returned to me chastened but intact, his wounds healed, his body restored.
Raphael: He thought I would dismember him but he has his uses so instead I am reeducating him.
Astarion: We delivered the devil. Now I want what I'm owed - we had a deal.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: Spill it - this sounds fascinating.
Astarion: I'd appreciate a little less enthusiasm when it comes to Cazador and his horrors.
Raphael: Oh come, Astarion. We're about to unveil your destiny - you should be quivering in anticipation.
Raphael: As you know already, your precious skin is home to one part of a contract between the archdevil Mephistopheles, and your former master, Cazador Szarr.
Raphael: In full, the contract states that Cazador will be granted knowledge of an infernal ritual so vile it has never been performed.
Raphael: The Rite of Profane Ascension.
Raphael: It promises to be a marvellous ceremony. Very elaborate, incredibly ancient, and entirely diabolical.
Raphael: If he completes the rite, he will become a new kind of being - the Vampire Ascendant.
Raphael: All the strengths of his vampiric form will be amplified, and alongside them he will enjoy the luxuries of the living.
Raphael: The arousals and appetites of man will return to him, and unlike you, he will have no need of a parasite to protect him from the sun.
Raphael: But the ritual has its price, as all worthwhile things do. Lord Cazador will need to sacrifice a number of souls, including all of his vampiric spawn, if he is to ascend.
Raphael: Imagine how he felt, then, when one of those precious spawn simply disappeared into thin air.
Raphael: The only missing ingredient is Astarion.
Raphael: You are the final piece he requires to complete the ritual - your scars bind you to it. Your soul will set off a very wave of death, bringing Cazador his twisted life.
Raphael: And that, my tragic and toothsome friend, is that. Now if you'll excuse me, I have business elsewhere.
NodeContext: [Tarik] snaps fingers at the end of the line.
Astarion: Hmm...
Player: You're... quiet. It's unsettling.
Astarion: It's a lot to take in.
Astarion: What do you think I should do?
Player: I think you should run. If Cazador can't find you, he can't complete his ritual.

Astarion: How long do you think I can run? He has eternity to find me.
Astarion: He'll never leave me alone. I didn't think he would when I was just one more wretched toy for him to play with.
Astarion: But if I'm the key to this power he craves, he'll hunt me to the ends of Faer√ªn.
Astarion: I need to take the fight to him.
Astarion: And I need you to help me.
Player: If he comes for you, I'll defend you. But we're not risking an attack on his lair.
Astarion: If you won't risk taking him on for my sake, think of the innocent souls he'll sacrifice in this ritual.
Player: The Absolute is a greater threat - we need to focus.
